newsitem.title: OMAN: Oman's Sultan decrees defence council membership.
newsitem.headline: Oman's Sultan decrees defence council membership.

text.p: Oman's Sultan Qaboos bin Said on Saturday issued a decree detailing the role and composition the Sultanate's defence council announced in November.

The council, to be headed by the Sultan himself, "will look into issues of state security and defence, and will confirm the successor which the Sultan will recommend in a letter to the ruling family, if the family fails to agree on a successor when the post of the Sultan becomes vacant," the decree said.
It said army, airforce, police, and customs chiefs would be members of the defence council. The Sultan's palace minister and the army chief of staff would also serve on the council.
Sultan Qaboos in November decreed Oman's "basic law", which diplomats said was the country's first written constitution.
They said the law was aimed at preventing a power vaccum or an internal struggle after his death.
The Sultan, 56, has had no heir apparent since he took over from his father in 1970. He is not married.

Oman, with a population of over two million, is a small independent oil producer and a member of the Gulf Cooperation Council which also groups Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Bahrain, Qatar and the United Arab Emirates.
